results.title: Look to the land
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows the wealth of natural resources in the United States and illustrates how they have been wasted or misused in the past. Then tours the country to see new farming methods, the wise management of timber and grazing lands, the co-ordinated development of river basins, and other efforts to preserve the natural heritage.

results.title: The Locker
results.creator_credit: Barry Tomblin and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: An experimental film about a young man and his involvement with a mysterious locker. During an interview voices emerge from the locker, later its resence torments him. The situation is treated in a surrealistic manner. Cast: James Dunkley, Paul Smythe, Nancy Gabrielle

results.title: Loch Lomond
results.creator_credit: Laurence Henson, Films of Scotland and IFA (Scotland)
results.brief_description: A study of human and wild life throughout the year, in, on, and around Loch Lomond. Gives a picture of the life and work of a Highland community - the wild life conservator, research biologist, shepherd, farmer and publican, all of whom know the Loch in its many moods.

results.title: Living with the city
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Examines recent developments in the preservation and rehabilitation of inner-city areas of Sydney, Adelaide and Melbourne raising the issue of low-income workers being forced out of these areas by “trendies” and high class shops. Highlights the need to strengthen working relationships between inner-city communities and government emphasising the importance of deeper official understanding of residents’ social and environmental needs. Narrated by Leonard Teale.

results.title: Living with dust
results.brief_description: Made for the Audio Visual Communications Centre, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co., the film presents causes of dust in nature and industry and gives methods of controlling these conditions. It tells how different dusts affect workers and what can be done to protect them.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 142
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Small particles of solid fuel burning in a bath of sand made fluid by air forms a bowl of liquid fire - a fire without waste or pollution; plants selectively bred for crops lose a great deal more water through their leaves than their genetic parents; application of a new spray prevents water loss; an electronic token radiates an “open sesame” signal to doors in a security area.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 124
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: A new mini tape-recorder, designed to record scientific information, helps patients undergoing tests for heart disease; five simple components are all that’s necessary to assemble one of the tiniest synchronous electric motors in the world; backache is frequently the result of taking life sitting down, and since most sufferers are unlikely to revert to a quadruped existence, a cushion has been designed to support our sagging systems.

results.title: Living things are everywhere
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Uses the story of a young boy’s discovery of the variety of living things to be found along a river bank and in the woods to explain that living things may be discovered almost anywhere and to stimulate interest in the study of plant and animal relationships.

results.title: Living stone
results.creator_credit: John Feeney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film shows the inspiration, often related to belief in the supernatural, behind Inuit sculpture. The Inuit’s approach to the work is to release the image he sees imprisoned in the rough stone. The film centres on an old legend about the carving of the image of a sea spirit to bring food to a hungry camp. Photographed at Cape Dorset, Boffin Island with Inuit stone carvers of Kingait and Kangiyak. Award winning documentary.
